channel.title: Network Administrator
channel.description:
I had a few questions that I need answered because I'm a little confused and the IT director at our school hasn't really helped me out that much.
I'm currently studying to become a network administrator and by the time I get my associates degree I will have taken all of the following classes, along with a few others:
[code] BUS-262 Project Management BUS-248 Business Communications CIS-140 Intro to Microsoft Client O 2011/SP CIS-241 Intro to Web Desgn & Mgmt.. 2011/SP CIS-258 Intro to Enterprise Databas CIS-260 Data Base CIS-295 IT Professional Practice Mg CNS-150 Networking Fundamentals CNS-151 Network Communication Cabli CNS-155 Intro to Routing and Switch CNS-170 PC Repair and Maintenance CNS-180 Intro to Microsoft Server CNS-210 Microsoft Network Managemen CNS-220 Advanced Microsoft Server CNS-225 Microsoft Enterprise Mgmt CNS-230 Information Security CNS-240 Open Source Networking [/code]
Anyways, the question at hand, the one that I am really confused about, is what certification should I be looking to get to help me become more marketable to future employers. I was reading around and I really got a lot of conflicting responses. I was hoping some of the people here could help me out.

item.title: Network Administrator
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Newty, post:5, topic:383155”][quote author=the bank link=topic=478932.msg3506325#msg3506325 date=1298175529]
I got cisco certification through a high school course
[/quote]

So I should get cisco or no…? I mean if you got it through a high school course it doesn’t seem as important.[/quote]

There are different levels of Cisco certification.

I think ultimately it depends what you want to end up administrating. If you were going into a Windows environment, the MS certs would probably be desirable, if you were going into a 100% Unix environment then RHCE or whatever would be useful, etc.

Ultimately I think they’re probably less important than a lot of other things, too.

Read full topic

item.title: Network Administrator
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

It seems so, Newty. It would be better to wait towards the end of your college course, just so that you know what you do and don’t know. Because there are many Cisco qualifications that start from very basic shit like computer systems and you can safely skip them and not be judged negatively by an employer for doing so, if they know their cisco stuff.

The ones you linked to seem to be again, most of the fundamentals, OSI, TCP/IP, etc that you’ll likely be learning on your course so maybe you could try and skip ahead and look for the more specialised qualifications. I wouldn’t personally know where to look for them as I had the course organised for me and was taught it.

[quote=“Newty, post:5, topic:383155”][quote author=the bank link=topic=478932.msg3506325#msg3506325 date=1298175529]
I got cisco certification through a high school course
[/quote]

So I should get cisco or no…? I mean if you got it through a high school course it doesn’t seem as important.[/quote]

There are many, many Cisco qualifications. Like I said, ones that range from some very basic stuff (like the early CCNA modules) to some pretty intense stuff up on CCNP and CCIE.

Read full topic

item.title: Network Administrator
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

So TL is this the right place to be looking http://www.cisco.com/web/learning/le3/le2/le0/le9/learning_certification_type_home.html If not can you point me in the right direction please. They expire every 3 years so I should probably wait until the last year of college before I take the exam, right?

Read full topic

item.title: Network Administrator
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Look for Cisco qualifications. You’ll be starting on CCNA and the later exploration courses are pretty good, the early CCNA 1 - 2 discovery courses are a bit of a waste of time for most people who are interested since all they teach are networking fundamentals which you’ll likely already know (Ethernet Encapsulation, etc).

In my experience from knowing people in the industry, looking at jobs in the industry and doing a bit of contract work, Cisco qualifications have been a decent thing to have and quite valuable when you get into the CCNP. They do expire every 4 years (or maybe a bit less), though.

Read full topic
